body: Some of the most congested parts of Brooklyn can expect "nightmarish traffic" virtually until the end of the century, transportation officials said yesterday, as reconstruction continues on the Brooklyn Bridge and work has begun on the Gowanus Expressway. A new chapter in the long, bad dream starts at noon tomorrow -- and will last until 6 A.M.
title: Driving in Brooklyn? Expect the Worst

body: Here is a sampling of tours by bus, van, helicopter and foot that are scheduled this fall in New York City. Dates and times are subject to change. body: An indictment was unsealed yesterday charging a Brooklyn woman with murder and arson involving a Sept. 12 fire that took the life of a New York City firefighter. The woman, 23-year-old Elizabeth Couret, who told the authorities that she lived in Cobble Hill, was charged with causing the fire in which the firefighter, Kevin C. Kane, was killed. The
title: METRO DATELINES; Indictment Names Woman in Fatal Fire

body: Hussein Jaber, a Palestinian who moved from Jerusalem to Brooklyn 12 years ago, has creatively adapted himself to life in Sunset Park -- one of New York City's most ethnically diverse neighborhoods -- by hanging a sign in his bodega's window, which caters to the area's large Hispanic population, saying "Mexican grocery." title: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council - An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council; Varied Interests Vie to Represent Brooklyn District

body: On a hot summer day, Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn near Borough Hall feels like Los Angeles, with here and there a solitary stroller beside four lanes of traffic. Except for the occasional gas station or car wash, there is little sign of habitation, and with the architectural bleakness comes a sense of isolation. The sun beats down and there is no
title: Sunday Outing; 3 Antiques-Rich Blocks in Brooklyn

author: Samuel G. Freedman, the author of "Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students and Their High School," is writing a book about a black church in Brooklyn.
body: "Jungle Fever," Spike Lee's new film, opens with a still photograph of Yusuf K. Hawkins, the black teen-ager killed by a white mob in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn two summers ago. But if the screen had remained blank, the memory of that murder would have suffused "Jungle Fever" just as palpably, for it explores the nexus of race, sex and
title: FILM; Love and Hate in Black and White

body: Tuesday's nonpartisan election to fill the City Council seat in Brooklyn's 29th District is important. The winner will have a clear advantage in the fall election when the Council expands to 51 members and comes into its own under the new City Charter. The tone of the campaign has been far from uplifting and makes a choice difficult. Nonetheless,
title: Joan Millman for City Council

body: Although Brooklyn's rich diversity of historic and architecturally distinct housing is far too much to be explored in a day, those interested in serious sampling may want to consider a bus tour being offered next Sunday by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. The nonprofit educational group, known until last July as the Prospect Park
title: Postings: History and Housing; Touring Brooklyn by Bus

body: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn has refused to lease two unused parochial school buildings to the New York City Board of Education because of his objections to a sex-education curriculum that would be taught in the schools. The board had sought the space to house 400 students in special-education programs and was willing to pay $3 million for
title: Citing Sex Classes, Bishop Bars School Leases

body: Having traveled the whole world in search of game fish, it still amazes me that the shortest fishing commute I have ever had is from my home in Cobble Hill in Brooklyn to the waters of New York Harbor. It's about a five-minute walk to the nearest pier and 10 minutes down to the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge, where, on an early winter's evening, I
title: OUTDOORS; Striped Bass and the Big City
